entry.title: Sewar Dghaim joins the group, welcome Sewar!

link.title: Sewar Dghaim joins the group, welcome Sewar!

entry.content:
Sewar Dghaim joins the group for a month as a Mic2XL fellow. Sewar is a graduate student in the computer science department at Governor State University.

At CNM, Sewar will work on using reinforcement learning to minimize Joule losses in memristive devices.

entry.title: Dr. Jithin George joins the group, welcome Jithin!

link.title: Dr. Jithin George joins the group, welcome Jithin!

entry.content:
Dr. Jithin George joins as a postdoctoral fellow. Prior to joining the group, Jithin completed his PhD in Applied Mathematics from Northwestern University. Jithin is supervised Dr. Valerie Taylor, Dr. Maria Chan, and Dr. Emil Constantinescu).

At CNM, Jithin will work on machine learning surrogates of the dielectric properties and the optimization of Lagrangians with funky non-conservative terms.

entry.title: Dr. Sraddha Agrawal joins the group, welcome Sraddha!

link.title: Dr. Sraddha Agrawal joins the group, welcome Sraddha!

entry.content:
Dr. Sraddha Agrawal joins the Center for Nanoscale Materials as a postdoctoral fellow! Prior to joining the group, Sraddha obtained her PhD in Chemistry from the University of Southern California.

At Argonne, Sraddha will work on developing an understanding and controlling optomechanical effects in low-symmetry materials using first-principles-informed calculations, reinforcement learning, and machine learning. This work is a close collaboration with the experimental group of Richard Schaller at CNM, and will immensely benefit from the wisdom and guidance of Steve Whitelam at the Molecular Foundry and the knowledge of the groups of Maria Chan and Subramanian Sankaranarayanan in CNM Theory and modeling group.

entry.title: Dr. Jing Trerayapiwat joins the group, welcome Jing!

link.title: Dr. Jing Trerayapiwat joins the group, welcome Jing!

entry.content:
Dr. Jing Trerayapiwat joins the group. Prior to joining the group, Jing obtained his PhD in Theoretical Chemistry from Boston University.

At Argonne, Jing will work on developing an exascale framework for coupled electro-thermal modeling of three-dimensional integrated devices to deploy on the upcoming exascale Aurora machine. This work will be in collaboration with Alvaro Vazquez Mayagoitia and Huihuo Zheng from the Computing, Environment and Life Sciences directorate at Argonne, and the CNM Theory and modeling group’s Maria Chan and Subramanian Sankaranarayanan.

entry.content:
The great Savannah Mitchem recently wrote a news story about our recently published work (Trainer et al., 2022) on artificial lattices made by carving the potential energy surface of the surface states of copper surfaces with carbon monoxide molecules.

The highlight can be found here. I link it despite my extreme bitterness at not coming up with the headline “I can’t believe it’s not graphene!”.

In other, related news, the work was also selected as a supplementary cover by ACS Nano, leading Dan Trainer to produce the following work of art.

entry.title: Incipit
entry.content:
We begin! Pierre starts as an Assistant Scientist at the Center for Nanoscale Materials. He will try his very best not to embarrass his incredibly patient past (Valerio Olevano, Didier Mayou, Jeffrey B. Neaton, Chris A. Marianetti, and Andrew J. Millis) and present (Stephen Gray) mentors, but will also keep this quote of Grothendiek in mind:

Discovery is a child’s privilege. I mean the small child, the child who is not afraid to be wrong, to look silly, to not be serious, and to act differently from everyone else. He is also not afraid that the things he is interested in are in bad taste or turn out to be different from his expectations, from what they should be, or rather he is not afraid of what they actually are. He ignores the silent and flawless consensus that is part of the air we breathe – the consensus of all the people who are, or are reputed to be, reasonable. —Alexander Grothendieck, Récoltes et Semailles (English version)

We look forward to years of candid discovery, and, while we can’t guarantee our research will be impactful, we can however promise to make honest mistakes rather than dishonest ones along the way.

Quickly, before we get started: Thank you, all. We love to tell ourselves we deserve it, and whether it is true or not, experience tells us stochasticity does govern most of our trajectories. Thanks to all the Maxwell demons out there, who, regardless how briefly or decisively they acted, made it possible. I won’t forget any of you, whether you want me to or not. Merci.
